misconceptions.name: Reads multiple coordinate values instead of a single numeric grade
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading one numeric grade between 0 and 100, the program reads four double values representing two points (x1, y1, x2, y2), which does not match the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should prompt for two points and read four doubles from the user for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt once for a single numeric grade (0–100) and read exactly one numeric value from the user.
symptoms: Program asks for coordinates rather than a grade
Four numbers are read instead of a single grade
No variable represents a numeric grade in the 0–100 range
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reused code for a different assignment (distance between points) or misunderstood the task prompt.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the coordinate prompts and four nextDouble() calls with a single prompt like "Enter grade:" and read one numeric grade value (e.g., an int or double).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All input handling is focused on reading coordinates; there is no variable or prompt related to a grade.

evidence.note: The program prompts for and reads two points instead of a single numeric grade value.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for A and B grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The program does not implement any conditional checks to determine whether the numeric input corresponds to an A (90–100) or B (80–89). It instead computes a distance between two points.
misconceptions.student_belief: I do not need to check numeric ranges for letter grades; I only need to compute and print a distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should use if/else-if conditions to check if the grade is between 90 and 100 for an A, or between 80 and 89 for a B.
symptoms: No if or else-if statements checking ranges like grade >= 90
No variable representing a grade that could be compared to thresholds
misconceptions.root_cause: Focus on solving a different problem (distance formula) instead of implementing the grade range logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a grade variable, then add if/else-if statements such as if (grade >= 90) { ... } else if (grade >= 80) { ... } to handle A and B ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditionals at all; the only computation is the distance formula.

evidence.snippet:
double dx = x2 - x1 ;  // difference in x
double dy = y2 - y1 ;  // difference in y

double distance = Math.sqrt ( dx * dx + dy * dy ) ;  // distance formula
evidence.note: The core logic computes a distance; there is no conditional logic that could implement A or B grade ranges.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for C and D grade ranges
misconceptions.description: There are no conditions checking whether the grade falls into the C (70–79) or D (60–69) ranges; the program does not handle these cases at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: Ranges for C and D are not needed because the program's task is to compute a distance, not map grades.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should include additional else-if branches to check for 70–79 (C) and 60–69 (D) once higher-grade ranges have been handled.
symptoms: No branching based on mid-range grade values
Program output is independent of any grade input
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a different algorithm entirely and therefore omitted all mid-range grade handling.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After handling A and B, add else-if (grade >= 70) { ... } and else-if (grade >= 60) { ... } blocks to cover C and D ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Complete absence of any grade-related conditionals strongly indicates missing C/D range logic.

evidence.note: Main method contains input and distance computation only; there are no grade variables or conditional statements for C/D ranges.

misconceptions.name: No default or else case for F grades
misconceptions.description: The program does not include any else or default handling for grades below 60 (F); it has no conditional structure at all, so F is never considered.
misconceptions.student_belief: There is no need for an else or default case because the program is not mapping grade values to letters.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: There should be a final else clause (or equivalent) that assigns an F to any grade below 60, after checking for A–D.
symptoms: No else branch to catch grades below a threshold
Program has no behavior that differentiates failing grades from passing grades
misconceptions.root_cause: The student did not design the solution around a grade-classification structure, so a default case for F was never introduced.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After handling A through D with if/else-if statements, add an else block that prints 'F' for all remaining grades.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Since no grade-related conditions exist, there is necessarily no default handling for F.

evidence.note: Program computes distance and immediately prints it; there is no branching structure where an else case for F could appear.
